title: take a breather harry make move back home
story: It is surely not too late for them to do a big, fat U-turn, especially when you see what their star power can achieve. It seems like such a waste for them to walk away.This week, Harry launched his Invictus Games with suitably stirring music and a passionate voiceover that showed how much he cares about this terric project, which helps wounded servicemen and women from all over the world.It is such a positive and effective way to give these heroes real purpose. Harry has been the driving force since it was little more than an idea on the back of a fag packet.The next day she made a low-key visit to young girls campaigning to combat climate change.Meghan was relaxed, caring and didn’t look for special treatment.Her visits were without pomp and fuss. You can tell it meant the world to everyone she encountered.She could easily have stayed in her mansion on Vancouver Island, closed the curtains and spent her days being pampered.Instead, she got up off her bottom and tried to do a bit of good for causes she cares about.It is admirable — but would the world have been as interestedthey were just plain old Harry and Meghan, without the aura of royalty And will the world’s Press still give such deserving causes the same level of attention this time next yearHarry and Meghan are no longer members of the Firm I’m not so sure. That’s why I would love them to slam on the brakes and reconsider their position.They can always rehire the staff axed from Frogmore House, especially as a move to Canada as “quasi royals” doesn’t look as welcoming as they first thought.Bedazzled PM Justin Trudeau at first promised that the famed Mounties would provide security and protection, but he has had to embarrassingly roll back on his offer and, while the extremely polite Canadians are happy to have Harry and Meghan as guests, they aren’t so keen on footing the bill to have them there permanently.The Queen would be thrilled to have her grandson back and the chance to get to know her great-grandson Archie properly.She would want to buy him his first pony and watch him learn to ride. He could grow up with his cousins George, Charlotte and Louis and be a proper part of the family.There are obviously tensions, hurt feelings and resentments within this clan. But surely the terribly British passive-aggressive arguments and niggles could be ironed out.It can’t really be too late to wipe the slate clean and start afresh.The first thing to be done is for Harry and Meghan to drop that daft court case against a British newspaper which printed a letter she had written to her dad, after he ­voluntarily handed it over.No one is going to come out of that fight with any dignity, and we don’t want to see Thomas Markle forced to give evidence against his daughter in court. They should concentrate their energies instead on trying to salvage their relationship, though I fear that ship has sailed.And brothers William and Harry need to go for a beer and sort out their gripes.Harry also needs to get back in touch with his old pals, who have been fiercely loyal and deeply hurt at being airbrushed out of his le.Surely an agreement can be hammered out which sees Harry and Meghan able to pursue their own causes without being stled by the Palace hierarchy, but also with everyone singing from the same song sheet and not constantly upstaging each other.I know the Queen wants Harry and Meghan’s new roles to be cut and dried as quickly as possible, with minimum fuss. But maybe what is needed is a bit of breathing space. Harry is due to go back to Canada in a couple of days to be reunited with Meghan and their young son.It might be a forlorn hope, but I would dearly like to see them having a rethink about their future and come back in from the Canadian cold.It would be a shamepride and stubbornness on both sides stopped them as I believe they would still get a warm welcome from the vast majority of us. It’s not too late.CAN we all just take a minute to salute the absolute force of nature that is Sun Online columnist and BBC presenter Deborah James Deborah has just been declared cancer-free – three years after a diagnosis of incurable bowel cancer and being given an EIGHT per cent chance of survival.Deborah is a walking miracle who has rewritten the textbooks and is giving hope to others living with the disease.She is also one of the kindest, sunniest, most decent women I know.She co-hosts the unmissable podcast You, Me And The Big C and is a regular on my TV show, where her funny, honest appearances have saved lives.Deborah takes every chance to spell out the symptoms of bowel cancer and encourage people not to be embarrassed about seeing a doctorthey notice any changes in their bowel movements.She has even laughingly nicknamed herself “Bowel Babe” to sht the silly stigma Brits feel about bums.As a result, people have had cancer detected early enough to get effective treatment, extending their lives.Sadly, Deborah’s heady news does not mean she is cured.This disease can rear its ugly head again, as Deborah knows all too well.But I hope she spends this weekend celebrating with friends, family and a large glass of wine, or by buying herself a sassy outfit and handbag.She’s a true inspiration. I’m proud to know her.She lost st after realising she was too heavy and wanted to be healthier for her son.Being overweight subjects you to all kinds of health problems. It is not about fat-shaming.You need to be sensible and take care of yourself.Adele has grafted to provide for her child and now has literally worked her ar*e off to make sure she is around for as long as possible. Good on her.THE new James Bond film is still a long way off, but speculation about who will succeed pouty Daniel Craig as  is reaching fever pitch.It seems that any cute actor to ever wear a tuxedo could be up for the part. My favourites for the role include Britain’s most handsome man Idris Elba, right – obviously – as well as Scotsman Richard Madden and the delectable Andrew Scott.Andrew was a villain in Bond’s previous big-screen outing, ’s Spectre, but let’s not hold that against him.If EastEnders’ Ben Mitchell can have SIX dferent heads over the years, we can surely ignore the slight inconvenience of Andrew’s scheming tech-terrorist trying to bump off all of MI.James Norton is another contender, but I have taken issue with him since catching up with The Trial Of Christine Keeler on BBC.It’s a slightly schlocky take on the infamous Sixties scandal involving the Tory cabinet minister John Profumo, who had a sexual relationship with Christine when she was just  – at the same time that she was “romantically linked” with Russian spy Yevgeny Ivanov.James plays society osteopath Stephen Ward, who acted as a sort of posh pimp and introduced Christine to Profumo in the first place. He is super-creepy in the series, with an intensely irritating habit of calling Christine “little baby” in almost every sentence.If you watch the show and sink a drink every time he utters those annoying words, you will be sloshed about ten minutes into each episode.It has taken the shine off Mr Norton for me, so I’m afraid he has to go to the back of the Bond queue.I AM convinced that when The Masked Singer’s Octopus character takes off its head, it will be revealed as model actress singer Caprice.I have absolutely no insider knowledge and only say this because Caprice actually released a single in the late Nineties.While doing the promotion rounds, on GMTV she very gamely warbled her song on a freezing beach while wearing not very much – in one of that show’s many fabulously surreal segments.If Caprice could cope with all that, then dressing up as a giant, eight-tentacled creature that can squirt black ink from its bottom would be a breeze.HUGH GRANT, who was absolutely brilliant in Paddington , is entitled to his opinion, like everyone . But I take real issue with him perpetuating the myth that tragic Princess Diana was “effectively killed” by British tabloid newspapers.Diana died in an accident because she was being driven by a drunk and didn’t have her seatbelt fastened. She had been stripped of her HRH title, which meant she didn’t have proper security, while the car was being driven too fast in a bid to elude bottom-feeding French paparazzi.To say the British Press were purely to blame is outrageous. And as Hugh Grant’s accusation went unchallenged during his appearance on US TV, most Americans will take it as gospel.They tend to believe posh actors who speak with cut-glass, upper-class accents.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince philip played by idris elba bbc
story: I genuinely believed that it was the gateto all we hold dear, and that it alone forced ITV and Channel  to make quality programmes. They had tothey wanted any viewers at all.Without Auntie, I reckoned that naked commercialism would take over and, soon, we’d end up with television like they had in Italy or Spain.Hours of incomprehensible game shows followed by a shouty weathergirl in not much of a bikini.But then along came Volvo sponsors Sky Atlantic with a host of dramas in which a Swedish detective in a jumper would solve crimes by staring into a lake for six weeks. We loved them.And then there was Amazon and Netflix, who realised thatwe were going to give them our money, they’d better bloody well give us some brilliant, intelligent shows in . So they did.All of this meant thatwe had the cash, we could get home after work and watch Breaking Bad or Ray Donovan or Dexter, or The Man In The High Castle or The Last Ship, or Ozark, or a Swedish woman staring into another lake, or Game Of Thrones, or The Sopranos or The Wire or  or ­Billions, or True Detective.Or we could watch a skateboarding duck on The One Show.Then there’s football. Right now,you’re a fan, you must pay BT, Sky and Amazon to stay in touch.That’s expensive, especially as you are also forced to pay your licence fee for a service that offers almost no live football at all. Or decent sport of any kind.To fight back against the onslaught of choice, the BBC has announced that by  . . . ready . . . drum roll . . . two-thirds of its staff will be based outside London.So what  Sure, you can have a technology hub in Newcastle and locate your Sounds app in Salford butall the decisions are still being made in Islington, over a plate of nuclear-free, vegetarian peace kale, it won’t make any dference.The fact is that the BBC is effectively governed by the monoculture that is social media. It’s ­terried of offending Twitter, so it abides by the rules.Far-right politics are bad. Far-left politics are fine. Veganism is good. Donald Trump is not.You get the impression thatthe BBC made The Crown, the Queen would be played by that guy in a wheelchair from Countryfile and Prince Philip by Idris Elba.And all they’d ever talk about, because all anyone ever talks about on any BBC show, is bloody climate change.I know it’s very noble but after a while, it becomes wearing. And I find myself sitting there ­thinking: “Oh for God’s sake, can’t they just have sex ”No. Obviously, no one can have sex on the BBC because a baby might result. And babies need food which, of course, causes global warming.The BBC was set up to “inform, educate and entertain”. Not “lecture, bombard and lecture again”.It’s got to the point now where the only BBC programmes I regularly watch are Pointless and Match Of The Day.I can’t even bring myself to listen to Attenborough any more. In the past, it was: “Look at this amazing fish which can breathe through its anus.”Now, it is: “Look at this amazing fish that can breathe through its anus and which is threatened by climate change.”Soon, it’s entirely possible the licence fee will become voluntary and when it does, the BBC will quickly learn that to ­survive it must make shows people want to watch.That’s people everywhere, not just ­Twitter people in a Shoreditch juice bar.Killing Eve. Fleabag. Earth’s Tropical Islands. More of that.And less of everything .So it’s good to see Meghan’s still working hard on behalf of those with mental-health issues.I’LL be honest. When it seemed likely that Mr Corbyn would win the General Election, I briefly entertained the idea of emigrating.I figured that there’d be no point living in the UKthe Government was going to take all my earnings and savings in tax.I even went so far as to go online and look at properties for sale in Italy. They all looked lovely – old stone farmhouses with pools – and all for less than a one-bedroom flat in Harpenden.But then I started to think: “Hang on. I don’t have any friends or family in Italy, so in about two hours I’d be lonely.”Then, the next day I’d drown my loneliness with a lunchtime drink, and then another.I’d make a rule that there’d be no drinking before , but soon I’d make that am.And within a month, I’d be pouring red wine on my cornflakes. Within a year, I’d be in a hospital trying to say, in Italian, to a doctor: “Please can I have a new liver ”I’m telling you all this because Harry and Meghan probably think le will be peachy by the sea in Canada.But home is where your friends are.And Harry’s friends, at least, are in the UK. He’s going to miss them. A lot. I guarantee it.WE have learned from American news footage that when there’s a small flood or some wind, we must go on the news and wail like stuck pigs about the injustice of it all.It makes me so angry that even my hair starts to itch.So I was delighted this week to see that when some floods came to the area where Jodie Kidd lives, she simply rolled up her trousers and carried on as normal.It does help, mind you, that she’s taller than The Shard.FOR reasons known only to a lunatic, it would cost £, to ring the bell in Big Ben to celebrate our departure from the EU.Hmmm. Seeing as the tower is currently hidden behind a million tons of scaffolding, why doesn’t someone go up there with a CD player and some big speakers We’d never know.THERE was further proof this week that the stock market is mad and everyone involved with it is Wolf Of Wall Street bonkers.Because apparently, City types now give Tesla a higher valuation than Ford and General Motors combined.Even though the electric minnow takes three months to produce what the big boys produce in a week.And is run by a dope enthusiast who calls random strangers “pedos” on social media. And gets away with it.A FRIEND of mine was driving along a dual carriageway this week when his super-green hybrid BMW i decided to have an electric duck fit.The power steering and power brakes both failed and it was only by using Herculean force he was able to coast, eventually, to a halt on the grass verge.He tells me that BMW hopes to have the car back to him very soon.But he’s not sure he wants it. He reckons he’d be better off with the petrol-powered M they’ve lent him in the meantime. Can’t say I blame him, really.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: great brexit blockage removed nation heal
story: The  referendum result will be delivered on and we will leave the European Union.Boris Johnson’s election ­victory has been the political equivalent of Dyno-Rod unblocking the drains of ­Westminster.In , our politics began to smell aseverything was stuck and nothing was moving.But the arrival of a majority government has changed all that. Not only is Brexit now sailing through Parliament, the Northern Ireland Assembly is back up and running after years in abeyance.Number  is now keen to get on with delivery.Ministers and advisers have been personally reminded that running their departments is far more important than appearing on television or ­talking to the media.Boris wants to restore the kind of Cabinet discipline we haven’t seen since the early Blair years. But moving forward also offers a chance to BRING THE COUNTRY BACK TOGETHER.As Boris’s great hero Winston Churchill used to say: “In ­victory, magnanimity.”At Prime Minister’s Questions this week, he took a much less confrontational style than usual.With everyone apart from the Labour and Scottish National Party leaders, he went out of his way to be generous and not score party-political points.Given that Boris likes to be liked, this is a more natural approach for him than being confrontational with every opposition MP.Boris wants to occupy the common ground. His approach to Brexit night on January  reflects that.Rather than being out with Nigel Farage and Co in Parliament Square, he will address the nation on this momentous moment from Downing Street.I am told the message will be upbeat but he will also try to reach out and reassure those who voted Remain. It would be tempting for Boris to join in some full New Year’s Eve-style celebration. And there are undoubtedly Leave voters who would love him to do just that.The danger is that this might alienate those who voted Remain but who have now reconciled themselves to the result and want to help the country pull together.What is key is that in the coming weeks, the Government shows it knows what it wants to do to improve voters’ lives. Boris must put meat on the bones of his plan to “level-up” infrastructure and opportunity across the country.He must show he knows not only how to keep the ­economy growing but how to get it out of second gear, which it has been stuck in — along with most of the West — since the financial crisis of .The next few months present a remarkable opportunity for the PM. He has a sizeable ­parliamentary majority and a united government, while both Labour and the Lib Dems are absorbed by their own leadership contests.This is his moment to really crack on.THIS week, the European Union Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan said it is “just not possible” to conclude everything on the UK’s future relationship with the EU by the December  deadline for the end of the transition period.But the UK and the EU both agreed to that timeframe in the political declaration.The EU shouldn’t have signed up to itthey didn’t think it was possible to agree things by that date.Boris Johnson is determined not to extend this transition period.He feels the whole process has gone on too long already. So there needs to be some compromise to keep things moving.What is key is that at the end of this year the UK is no longer sending millions to the EU every day the UK determines its own immigration policy and the role of the European Court of Justice in the UK ends on all matters other than the rights of EU citizens.THE Royal Family is in its worst crisis since the death of Diana.By contrast, Boris Johnson is determined to stay out of the current drama.BORIS JOHNSON’S refusal of Nicola ­Sturgeon’s demands for a second Scottish independence ­referendum was definitive.But it will become very hard to ­continue to refuse those callsthe SNP wins a majority at next year’s Scottish Parliament elections, in a campaign dominated by the ­question of whether or not there should be a second referendum.On a list of things that could derail this Government, Scotland is very high up the list.The best way to stop that happening is for the Tories, along with the other unionist parties, to deny the SNP an absolute majority at Holyrood in .That will require the Government to pay more attention to ­Scotland and be more prepared to call out the SNP on its ­domestic policy failures.THE first public hustings of the Labour leadership contest take place today – and the race looks set to be hard fought.A survey this week putting Shadow ­Business Secretary Rebecca Long Bailey ­narrowly ahead has dented the idea that Shadow Brexit ­Secretary Keir Starmer has it in the bag. It doesn’t look like the contest is going to be a particularly comradely affair.The personal jabs are already coming and the election isn’t over until April. Starmer and Long Bailey are the two front- runners. The Tories believe both candidates provide them with opportunities.Long Bailey wants to continue the Corbyn project. She will not bring Labour back towards the mainstream of British politics. Starmer, though, is the architect of the parliamentary manoeuvring on Brexit and the second ­referendum policy that hurt Labour so badly in those Red Wall constituencies lost in the election.As one Tory grandee puts it: “If they go for Keir, they’re locking in a problem with those Leave-voting seats.”The dark horse is Lisa Nandy. She performed best in the hustings for Labour MPs, put in a far better performance with interviewer Andrew Neil than Jeremy Corbyn did and is picking up some interesting endorsements.The longer this contest goes on, the better she will do. But even Nandy is making missteps and ­providing the Tories with ammunition in the event she becomes leader.This week, she defended free movement. She claimed voters in towns of the North and Midlands weren’t really opposed to it.This flies in the face of the fact that so many of these places voted Leave in , then flipped to the Tories in last month’s “Brexit election”.Nandy won’t pay an immediate price for this misstep, as most Labour members are pro-free movement themselves.But her decision to speak out shows how focused the contest is on Labour’s “selectorate” and not the broader electorate.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris unifying speech outside no10
story: He is walking a tightrope between jubilant Leavers and disconsolate Remoaners . . . with most of the population somewhere between.So a unying speech outside No at pm is a must. A laser display, countdown clock and a mass of Union flags all sound good.Big Ben’s bongs were scuppered by Commons authorities. So why not get the BBC to play them at that pivotal moment  And Leavers wanting the full party can still join Nigel Farage in ­Parliament Square.We note the EU’s Guy Verhofstadt cheering himself up with the fantasy of us rejoining one day. Sorry, Guy.Our economy will now have global opportunities. His is forever crippled by the euro. No government will shackle us to that.As for millions of UK-based EU citizens whose rights he is worried about, our system is simple, free and now working well.It’s high time Brussels strong-armed all its members into being equally generous to OUR expats.So far, disgracefully, they have not.IF Harry and Meghan have now moved away for good we wish them the best.So long as they relinquish their titles, all handouts from the Duchy of Cornwall and Sovereign Grant, and refund £.million the public lavished on the house they abandoned in nine months.We are sorry Meghan found her “soul crushed” by Royal le so soon after she enthusiastically married into it.And that she found Britain insufficiently welcoming despite her joyous national celebration of a wedding, for which the public happily paid £million and to which a besotted Press devoted entire editions.It is oddHarry failed to warn her what she might expect, but there we are.Happy mansion hunting, Mr and Mrs Wales!HE may not be a household name, but we salute actor Laurence Fox.It takes guts to defy the suffocating liberal-left or Corbynite consensus in the arts and admit you’re of the centre right. Maybe others will now join him in coming out of the political closet.It cannot be lost on them — with Brexit, the Tories’ huge majority, Ricky Gervais exposing Hollywood hypocrisy and the public anger at the Waleses — that years of hysterical, “woke” dominance of the national conversation looks like ending.It’s probably too much to hope that even the BBC is finally getting the message. But, bizarrely, three right-wing lists outnumbered an idiot Corbynista and an SNP complainant on Thursday’s Question Time.Someone must surely be fired.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schoolgirls tampons sanitary towels free
story: Ministers have vowed to give free period products to all girls at state schools and colleges in England.They say the move will means kids don’t miss class because they cannot afford tampons.Children’s minister Michelle Donelan said: “Periods are a normal part of everyday le and we do not want young people missing out on lessons because of them.“We know that it is not easy for everyone to access period products where and when they need them.“This scheme will deal with those problems so young people can go about their daily lives without getting caught outthey have come on their period unexpectedly, forgotten to bring products with them orthey can’t afford the products they need.”One in ten young women in the UK have been too poor to buy sanitary products, research carried out by the charity Plan UK in  found.Rose Caldwell, chief executive of Plan International UK, said: “We know that some girls miss school because they don’t have period products, and that they have had to use items like toilet roll and socks because they can’t afford anything .“So having access to a range of period products at school will make a very real dference to many girls’ lives.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy vanished motorway dad nine hours
story: The boys dad, Umair Rahim, has told how he kept praying that his son Aadil would be found safe and well after he went missing at Newport Pagnell Services near Milton Keynes.The frantic dad said: I had every faith that the police would find him.My faith helped me through a very dficult time.He said that his we, who had stayed at home with their younger son, had feared the worst but he “never gave up hope.”The six-year-old had got lost and disorientated on Friday evening after going to the loo at a service station on the M.After being spotted by a helicopter nine hours later, the little lad, who only had a jumper to keep him warm, was reunited with his dad.More than , members of the public helped in the search for the schoolboy.Umair, , speaking exclusively to The Sun Online from his home in Nottingham said: “My boy was thankfully found safe.That’s all that matters. I never stopped hoping and police kept reassuring me they’d find him.He has no idea about all the fuss surrounding him.He had been wandering up and down the side of the motorway after going to the toilet and when he came out he couldn’t find the coach and he got lost from the rest group.Umair, who runs a used car dealership, told how the horror unfolded when he got a call from the police saying his son was missing.The pupil at a school in Nottingham had been on a coach trip to London to visit some off the sights and a museum.The group stopped for a break at Newport Pagnell Service Station near Milton Keynes, Bucks, before continuing with their -mile journey north to Nottingham.Umair said: “You hear of children going missing and never being found after many years like the girl Madeleine McCann.But with my son we knew he couldn’t have gone far and was hopefully still somewhere nearby.“At the time you don’t really know but I couldn’t let silly thoughts get inside my head.I had to stay strong and hopeful. He hadnt been snatched by anyone, he had wandered off and got lost.Thankfully he didn’t get onto the M, he remained at the side of the motorway.”Umair said that his relatives and close friends were relieved to hear the good news of the six-year-olds .Aadil, however, was busy playing with his brother before being told by his parents to “get some sleep.”He said: “I cannot thank the police and local community enough. title: haiti earthquake kiki thanks sun readers
story: In a remarkable story of survival, the seven-year-old lad had been buried for EIGHT DAYS with no food or water in the ruins of his home, alongside the leless bodies of two brothers and a sister.The miraculous moment when rescuers pulled him free was caught on camera and beamed around the world.Now The Sun on Sunday has tracked down Kiki, who gave his heartfelt thanks to you, our army of generous readers, for “saving his le” a second time after raising cash to fund his education.He now plans to save others by training to ­become a doctor.Kiki, , said: “Thank you to all of the Sun readers who helped to save my le.“Without an education, God knows what would have happened to me and my brother.“Thank you all from both of us. We are studying hard and it won’t be wasted, as we will help others and do good with our lives.“I want to be a doctor. That’s because of what happened to me and my family. I know how lucky I am.”Kiki told how he has spent the past decade rebuilding his le alongside the surviving members of his family, including his mum Garcia, .More than , people died and a million children were orphaned when the tragedy struck on the afternoon of January , .Along with the  Indian Ocean tsunami, it is the worst natural disaster in modern times.The photo of Kiki’s rescue was used on the cover of The Sun’s  Helping Haiti ­charity single Everybody Hurts, which spent two weeks at No.In the eight days before he was rescued, Kiki lay alongside the bodies of his sister Yeye, nine, and -month-old brother Didine, who both died instantly when their home collapsed.Kiki and his other sister Sabrina ducked for cover under a table with their four-year-old brother Titite.Kiki sang his brother nursery rhymes and chatted to comfort him but Titite died before ­rescuers reached them.Sabrina, now , and another brother, David, now , who was playing outside when the magnitude-seven quake struck, both survived.The family home in the suburb of Nazon, in the Haitian capital Port-au-Prince, was destroyed — like all the others around it — leaving a ft pile of rubble.Garcia managed to free herself but was unable to reach her children.Recalling the quake, Kiki said: “I was doing my homework and there was a really loud noise.“I didn’t know what it was, then our house fell on me. I was in darkness and couldn’t see anything but I started shouting to my brothers and sisters.“I heard my mum as she managed to free herself and David was outside.“I was lying down, buried. I couldn’t move my body and after a few days I was hurting all over, as I couldn’t move and couldn’t even sit.“The only thing I was able to do was sleep and wake up. I lost two brothers and one of my sisters.“After it happened, we were talking to my brother. But after a few days he didn’t answer any more.Before that I didn’t think I would die. But when he died, I remember thinking, ‘I’m going to die too’. It was dark.“I had dust in my face, eyes and mouth and I didn’t have food. I can’t remember much but I do remember I was calling out for water.“I don’t know how long it was but it was a long time.“Then they found a little hole and put a piece of tube down to me.  They started pouring water down to me before they could free me.”Kiki, who lost all concept of time while he was buried, added: “One day, the light opened up a bit and part of the rubble was pulled out. And there was a big hole.“I saw the people who saved me outside. I was so happy and I lted my arms into the air.“I don’t remember saying anything to the rescuers but I remember everyone being so ­surprised.“They were shocked to see me alive. Then I remember having an oxygen mask put on me.After four hours of digging, a -strong rescue team including New York police and firefighters – punched through the layers of crushed concrete that entombed Kiki.There, the boy had huddled with his sister next to the corpses of their other siblings for eight unimaginable days.Some of the rescuers gained expertise amid the horrors of -.In the right of the picture above is the yellow hose down which water trickled to Kiki, who was suffering from extreme dehydration.Kiki, then seven, greeted his mum – on the picture’s left – with outstretched arms and a broad grin. He later said: “I smiled because I was free. Because I was alive.”His rescue caught made front pages around the world – including The Sun.A host of top artists recorded R.E.M.’s Everybody Hurts for our charity single, with Kiki – dubbed an “icon of hope” – on the record’s sleeve.“I feel proud that my photo went around the world. It was a miracle as after eight days, it was only God that could help me to be alive.”Kiki has never met the heroes who saved him but he promised he would never forget them. With emotion flickering across his face he said: “I want to thank all of those who saved me. Thank you.”After the tragedy, Garcia moved the family to a village  miles away, as they had nothing.Today they share their modest home with Kiki’s uncle Fefet, , and his great-aunts Tata, , and ­Elemise, .Kiki said: “I was so sad to leave our home. I had friends and I’d gone to school there.“But after ten years I’m getting ­better. I’m less sad. I’m trying to get to how I used to be.”In the aftermath of the disaster, The Sun joined forces with British charity Bridge Of Hope, which funds the education of children across the developing world.You chipped in with donations to help founder Lisa Yacoub fund the boys’ education at the National School of Lavanneau.The charity also helps children in Ethiopia, Uganda, India, Zimbabwe and Kenya and sponsors a school that focuses on a vocational ­education, including plumbing and dferent trades, in Port-au-Prince.Lisa said: “We rely completely on the generosity of the public to fund an education for the children we help.We are delighted to continue to help Kiki and David get an ­education but we are a tiny charity in urgent need of funds for this work to continue.“Kiki still has four years to go before he completes his education. We are grateful to The Sun’s readers for helping us to change these children’s lives.“We are committed to Haiti because well over half the population live on less than £. a day, which is below the international poverty line.“These kids really need our help. Without an education, their le would be dficult. They would face being destitute.“It is awe-inspiring to witness the resilience of Kiki’s family, who are rebuilding their lives after such extraordinarily challenging circumstances.”Kiki said: “I can now hope for a better future. I study very hard.“I’m very happy to have an ­education because this is how I can become a stronger person and help my family and others. I would like to be a great doctor.“I also enjoy music in my spare time and I play the guitar.”His mum Garcia added: “Thank you all for helping my sons have a future. I hope God blesses you. We will never forget you.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: prince harry meghan markle megxit demands
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex had released the bombshell announcement they were stepping down as royals before crunch talks with the Queen, with details of how it would work finally released last night.And while some questions remain over the couples future, heres what we know Harry and Meghan wanted - and what they got.Prince Harry and we Meghan Markle clearly wanted to keep their titles as Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Launching their news SussexRoyal website after their news, they also reportedly trademarked  items including pencils and bookmarks six months ago.Even their Instagram is hinged on their titles, which were given to them by the Queen on their wedding day.Throughout the Queens statement released last night, the couple were referred to as the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, which suggests they will keep these titles.Now, their names will be re-styled as Harry, Duke of Sussex and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex - similar to how his late mothers title was re-styled to Diana, Princess of Wales after she orced Prince Charles.And while they will be officially His and Her Royal Highnesses, they will not be allowed to use the titles anymore.But there was a slight confusion over this decision last night, with the couple immediately after releasing a statement that signed off Their Royal Highnesses.Prince Harry will remain sixth-in-line to the throne.Prince Harry and Meghan will get to keep Frogmore Cottage as their UK family home but they have agreed to repay the £.million of taxpayer money that was used to refurbish it.The couple are expected to pay commercial rent for the home and for its upkeep which could come to around £, a month.It seemed like the couple were willing to make this concession as they up sticks and move part-time to Canada,In the Queens statement last night, Buckingham Palace said the couple had shared their wish to repay” the public funds after moving in last spring.The public paid for kitchen, bathrooms and fitted wardrobes, as well services of a renowned interior designer.Her Majesty has allowed Harry and Meghan to keep their patronages but they can no longer formally represent the Queen.This appears to dfer to what the couple had initially wanted when they released their bombshell news about stepping down as royals.On their new Sussex Royal website, the couple said they wanted to aim to continue to fly the flag for Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, as called upon.However, the Queen seemingly knocked back this offer, with Buckingham Palace saying they can no longer formally represent the Queen.In another potential blow to Prince Harry, he will no longer keep his military titles.The royal had previously been the Captain General of Marines, Hon Air Commandant, Commodore-In-Chief and Youth Ambassador.Harry will no longer be a patron of the Royal Marines, the Royal Naval Commands Small Ships and Diving nor the Royal Air Force Honington.Prince Harry will be able to continue his work with the Invictus Games and Aids charity Sentebale but only as a private inidual.One of the matters the couple were the most clear on when it came to their future was their desire to be financially independent.Making the bombshell announcement ten days ago, they said financial independence is something they look forward to.The Queen appears to have given the green light for this, agreeing: They will no longer receive public funds for Royal duties.Prince Charles will continue to privately fund the royal couple after it was announced they can no longer use public funds.It is unclearthe money will continue to come from the Duchy of Cornwalls coffers - they get an estimated £.million a year from it.However, its unclear exactly who will fund their security.The couple had appeared to suggest they wanted the taxpayer to continue paying their security bill.But Buckingham Palace said: Buckingham Palace does not comment on the details of security arrangements.There are well-established independent processes to determine the need for publicly-funded security.When Harry and Meghan announced they were stepping back as Royals, they listed their work with the Commonwealth as something they were most proud of.They wrote: Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are honoured to help fulfil this potential through their roles as President and Vice President, respectively, of The Queens Commonwealth Trust.The Duke of Sussex was also given the role of Commonwealth Youth Ambassador by Her Majesty The Queen in .However, after last nights announcement, Prince Harry has been forced to give up his Commonwealth role with Sentebale.He is still allowed to work for them, but in a private capacity.The SussexRoyal website went into great s as to how press would be handled as they moved back from their roles as royals.They particularly cancelled their involvement in the Royal Rota which allows UK press to cover events that Royal Family members attend.Instead, they said they wanted to engage with grassroots media organisations and young, up-and-coming journalists.While the Queen did not mention what would happen in the future, she did indicate she understood the intense scrutiny they had faced.The deal will start in the spring and follows a summit among senior royals last Monday to discuss the couple’s wishes to step back from frontline duties.Royal protocol expert Alastair Bruce said Prince Harry has now been brought down to the level of  other Dukes in the UK. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGordon Brown has dismissed Boris Johnsonaposs plan to move the House of Lords to York as a cosmetic gesture that would do little to address the challenges the nation faces.The Labour former Prime Minister will use a major speech on Monday to warn that only radical constitutional change will help reconnect the people with national politics. He will say: “The Conservatives are accepting the need for change but clearly cannot contemplate the scale of change needed. We must reboot and renew Britain or we risk losing it. “An outdated institution  miles or so north of its current location is still an outdated institution.” Mr Brown will call for a UK-wide constitutional convention and regional citizens’ assemblies to gauge public opinion.He will suggest setting up a Forum of the Nations and Regions to prevent a centralisation of power in London after Brexit . This could then form the basis for a new second chamber that would ultimately replace the House of Lords. The Labour heavyweight also wants the Treasury to hand over powers over allocation of regional spending to local authorities, mayors and MPs sitting on a “Northern Exchequer” board.  “On vital issues, outlying regions and communities will no longer be governed simply by dictates from London second guessing what they want,” he will say.   “The demand for more power to the North is far greater than can be met by gimmicks or gestures given that the UK is a unitary state but a multinational country that it is asymmetric with  per cent of the votes at elections in England and that political, financial and administrative power has been over-concentrated in one city in the South.” The speech at a Hope Not Hate event in Westminster comes after it emerged Mr Johnson was considering moving  peers permanently to York in a major sht of British political gravity. Under the plans, the House of Commons would also go on tour - holding debates in cities outside of London.  York, sometimes referred to as “the capital of the North”, is reportedly the preferred option but Birmingham is also in the running. The exact location would be decided by a constitutional review, announced in the Tory manesto and launched in the Spring, which would also look at the powers and role of the Supreme Court and Lord Chancellor. Tory party chairman James Cleverly confirmed the government was considering moving the House of Lords to a Northern city. Disused government-owned land close to York railway station has already been identied as a potential site.  He told Sky’s Sophy Ridge programme: “What we are looking at is a whole range of options about making sure every part of the UK feels properly connected from politics.  “When the PM stood up the day after the election and said this is going to be the people’s government he meant it. That meant connecting people with government and politics.”

story: NewsMum who bought house of horrors says flowers wouldnt grow where bodies buriedEXCLUSIVE: The murders of Patricia and William Wycherley case are being dramatised in a Sky TV series starring Oscar winner Olivia Colman. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum who bought a house where two murder victims were buried in the garden has told how no flowers would grow over the spot where the bodies lay. For seven years Sue Bramley remained unaware of her home’s dark past and was baffled as all her bedding plants, lawn seed and turf died. Eventually she installed a patio, where she and her family would sunbathe and enjoy barbecues together. Then police searching for previous owners Patricia and William Wycherley, both missing, arrived to dig up the slabs. And they unearthed the couple’s corpses in a ft-deep grave. They had been killed for their money and buried by their daughter Susan and her husband Christopher Edwards, who were both convicted of the  double murders and jailed for le. The heart-rending case is being dramatised in a four-part Sky TV series, with Oscar winner Olivia Colman as Susan Edwards. Nurse Sue, , fears that her home will be a magnet for ghoulish sightseers when Landscapers is screened this year. But she said: “I have no intention of leaving.” She recalled her shock when police, acting on a tip-off, started digging up her back garden in  and told her: “We have found human remains.”  Sue, who moved to the house at Forest Town, Notts, in  with daughter Sophie, , said: “I went to pieces after seeing them taken away in body bags. “I was so upset to think that those two poor old people had been buried in my garden for all that time. “We went away for the weekend and by the time I got home on Monday the police had filled in the hole and removed their tents, so the garden was almost back to normal. “Detectives eventually confirmed that Mr and Mrs Wycherley had been killed in my bedroom.”  Sue recalled seeing the police teams digging around where Sophie had lain a flower bed. “I watched in horried fascination as their snfer dogs focused on that particular patch of garden by the back door, where oddly we’d never been able to grow flowers or plants,” she said. “Also I thought of how my four-year-old nephew used to bury his toy cars in the garden and his five-year-old sister would then have to try to find them. “I was aghast at what they could have found.” The police believe that gun fanatic Christopher Edwards, , shot his ­in-laws at point-blank range with a Second World War . revolver as his we Susan, , looked on.  After burying their victims in the back garden, the evil couple pretended that Patricia, , and Bill, , were alive to steal £, in their names. They kept up the pretence for  years. Using forged documents, they sold the Wycherleys’ house, claimed their £-a-month pensions, took out loans by posing as the dead couple and filched disability benefits. Childless Susan, once a police civilian clerk, replied to letters and cards written by relatives to her parents – signing off as them. She and her husband were both convicted and sentenced in  over the murders.  Even though Sue now knows the full ghastly truth about her House of Horrors, she insists: “I love it here.” She has planted a bush on her patio in memory of the murdered couple and said: “What was done to the Wycherleys was awful and no one deserves to die like that. “I often think about them – but this has never deterred me from living here. It is a lovely house and I like the area.

The terms of the coupleaposs departure from the royal family were revealed yesterday evening, ending a week and a half of speculation about their future in The Firm. Once the pair depart in the Spring, they will be known as Harry, Duke of Sussex, and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. Currently they are referred to as the Duke and Duchess of Sussex. The small, somewhat subtle change follows the precedent of Harryaposs mum Diana. When the Princess was stripped of her HRH title in  - following her orce from Prince Charles - she became known as Diana, Princess of Wales. Harry, Meghan and Archie will always be much loved members of my family. I recognise the challenges they have experienced as a result of intense scrutiny over the last two years and support their wish for a more independent le. I want to thank them for all their dedicated work across this country, the Commonwealth and beyond, and am particularly proud of how Meghan has so quickly become one of the family. It is my whole familyaposs hope that todayaposs agreement allows them to start building a happy and peaceful new le.  The declaration came at the end of a turbulent week and a half for the couple. At .pm this evening statements from Buckingham Palace and The Queen gave details of the deal struck between the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and the Queen. The victorious central point from Harry and Meghanaposs perspective is that they have been granted permission to step back from their royal duties. They have also been given the green light to spend a majority of their time away from the UK, most likely in Canada. In winning these freedoms however, Harry has had to shed large parts of the royal le he has lived for the past  years. A big change is the way the coupleaposs finances will work. While Harry will still have the multi-million pound inheritance he received from his mother Princess Diana, as well as an undisclosed annual sum from the Duchy of Cornwall, his outgoings will increase signicantly. Although he will remain a Duke, he will be HRH in name only.  Another key dference for Harry are the patronages that he will be keeping. Both he and Meghan will retain their personal patronages of charities, but the Prince will lose his official association to the military organisations he currently represents. From the Spring he will no longer be a patron of the Royal Marines, the Royal Naval Commandaposs Small Ships and Diving nor the Royal Air Force Honington.  The couple will also no longer go on royal tours. Most recently they went together to South Africa, Malawi, Angola and Botswana. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTemperatures plunged to almost -C overnight as a cold snap deepened - and health experts have issued an urgent warning about freezing weather. The coldest place in the UK was Topclfe in North Yorkshire, where it was a frigid -.C in the early hours of Sunday. It was followed by Benson, Oxfordshire , Katesbridge in Co Down, Northern Irelandand Derrylin in Co Fermanagh . The Met Office said Northern Ireland experienced its coldest night of the winter, while temperatures of -C were felt across London - and the chilly conditions are set to continue this week amid a warning from Public Health England. Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkhill said a fog warning had been put in place over sections of the West Midlands and north-west England. In many places, Britons woke up to their cars and gardens covered in frost. Mr Burkhill said: Itaposs been a very frosty start but through the bulk of the day itaposs going to be largely fine and largely sunny. It would still be quite chilly with expected highs of C scattered across parts of England, Mr Burkhill added.  He said that there would be some rain for the Shetland Islands. Rain is also possible near coasts in south-eastern places. Temperatures will peak at about -C across the country.  Meanwhile, the fog warning is in place for parts of England, including Manchester, Liverpool and Birmingham, and North Wales until pm on Sunday. A mid-range cold weather alert has been issued by Public Health England from pm on Sunday to pm on Tuesday.  The organisation is urging people to prepare for cold weather conditions and look out for those most at risk, especially the elderly. Dr Owen Landeg, principal environmental public health scientist at PHE, said: Below  degrees, changes to the body mean that the risk of strokes, heart attacks and chest infections increase so heating homes to this temperature is particularly important to stay well. Police have urged drivers not to leave their vehicles to defrost after an unattended car was stolen in Hertfordshire.  The vehicle was taken after it was left with its engine running on a driveway in Hemel Hempstead on Saturday morning. It was later found on its roof after crashing nearby Met Office five-day weather forecast Sunday Fog patches in the west could persist all day in a few places. Otherwise, mostly dry with sunny periods after a frosty start. The odd shower near coasts in the south-east, whilst cloudier and windier in the far north.

title: voice mirror megan harry cant
story: NewsopinionThe Voice of The Mirror: Meghan and Harry cant have the chateau and the gateauThe Queen has acted decisively but compassionately, firmly but proportionately, after Prince Harry and Meghan Markle attempt to have their cake and eat itShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionMegan and Harry want to have their cake and eat it " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhen Meghan and Harry decided to walk away from the Royal Family, and the duties that entails, they hoped to have their cake and eat it. Last night the Queen took that cake away. She made clear to her grandson and his we that self-banishment for a cushy le in Canada will come at a cost – and now the couple are handing £.million back to the taxpayer for tarting up their ­Frogmore Cottage home. But the most eye-catching change in their circumstances is that they will not be using their HRH titles. This is how it should be. Only those who do the work of Royal Highnesses should be allowed to call themselves such. If they are planning to endorse commercial products to make a few bob that is not a label they can attach to them. The Queen has acted decisively but compassionately, firmly but proportionately. As always, she is to be commended for her good sense. We’re saddened Harry and Meghan felt the need to escape, but the now semi-detached royal couple have learned a lesson ordinary folk face every day.  Decisions have consequences. And there is no such thing as free cake. Give kids hope We can only imagine the agony of parents Nikki and Lee when six-year-old daughter Briena told them she wanted to die. This clearly called for professional intervention to ensure Briena did not carry out the dreadful threat to take her own le. But the response was scandalously lacking. Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services said Briena was too young to be at risk. Repeated referrals did not get Briena the help she so desperately needed.  It was only when she made suicide attempts aged , and ended up in AE, that her ­condition was taken seriously. This is unacceptable. Suicide rates in young girls have risen  per cent over six years. Ministers talk a lot about improving care for children with mental health issues. But Briena is living testimony that they are not doing enough about it. Boris a turn-off At first sight it looks asBoris Johnson is doing us all a favour by telling his Cabinet ministers they are not to swan around on TV any longer. But have we got news for you. The PM’s move is not about sparing us boredom. It’s about manipulation and control.

title: a special feel about scottish cup mcpake
story: Dundee manager James McPake admits there is “a special feel” about Dens Park this week as the Scottish Cup comes around.The Dark Blues’ recent record in the competition hasn’t had too many high points but that isn’t stopping James looking forward to enjoying his first taste of the competition as a manager.As a player, he scored in a Scottish Cup Final defeat while playing for Hibs and is keen for his players to enjoy a similar run in the competition under his watch as boss.He said: “It is the old cliche, ‘the romance of the Scottish Cup’ but there is a special feel to it.“Motherwell are expected to come here and win as they are the Premiership club but we will have a right go and we can’t wait for it.“We will be facing an opposition that’s dferent from what we normally face in terms of they will come here with a real attacking threat.“The only other two teams who have done that this season are Dundee United and Ayr United.“Motherwell will be the same –they will just come out and have a right go like they do when they go to the likes of Celtic Park.“That’s the way they play. I like watching them when they go forward but we need to find a way to hurt them with our style of play as well.“It should be a good game for people to watch.”Saturday’s visitors Motherwell have enjoyed an impressive season in the top flight, sitting in the best-of-the-rest position in third behind the runaway top two of Rangers and Celtic.Stephen Robinson has been in charge at Fir Park for almost three years now and has overseen an upwards trajectory of the club.Dens boss James, though, isn’t shocked to see the Steelmen flying high this term, however.He added: “No, it hasn’t surprised me.“You can see why the manager has been successful with his recruitment and the way they play.“They can beat any team in that league from what I’ve seen of them this season.”This season is Motherwell’s th in the top-flight after last playing in the second tier in .And that sort of longevity at the top table of Scottish football is something Dundee should be enjoying, according to their manager. vw, px"  James added: “They have been in that league for as long as I can remember.“I said this at the start of the season – five years isn’t long enough for a club like ours to be in the Premiership .“People were saying we had a good run at it but no we didn’t.“We should be in it every year – as should our neighbours.“When you look at Scottish football, you want the derbies.“It was horrible when Hearts and Hibs weren’t in the same league so you didn’t have the Edinburgh derbies and it was the same when Rangers and Celtic weren’t in the same league.“The Dundee one is all right just now because we are both in the Championship.“But, for me, you want the better games in your top league.“But going back to that question, yes, we want to be a club that can sustain a position in the top league for  years or beyond.“Looking back at Motherwell, to be there from  is a long time staying in a league.“We did five – it is not enough.“We need to get back up and stay there.“The problem is, there are loads of teams saying that.“Not many can do it so credit to Motherwell.”Kick off on Saturday is .pm at Dens Park with the match shown live on BBC Scotland.

title: chip shop proposal for former cop shop on fintry road is rejected

title: dundee 0 3 motherwell steelmen stroll to cup win at dens as home fans stay away
story: Motherwell eased into the fth round of the Scottish Cup with a - win over Dundee at a sparsely-filled Dens Park.Just , home fans turned up to see their side take on the Steelmen and suffer yet another disappointing home defeat.First-half goals from Chris Long had the Premiership side in control before any hopes of a second-half comeback were extinguished following a Jack Hamilton howler to gt Long his third of the evening.Dark Blues boss James McPake made three changes to his side from their last outing as Declan McDaid and Jamie Ness ed from injury. Shaun Byrne also came in as Fin Robertson, Danny Johnson and Sean Mackie dropped out. New loan signing Ross Callachan was on the bench.Former Dees Declan Gallagher and Mark O#Hara started for the Steelmen.The top-flight visitors had the better of the opening stages and created the first chance of note as Liam Polworth turned the ball goalwards. Hamilton was equal to that in the Dundee goal before James Scott flashed a fierce effort just wide of the far post.On  minutes, the Dark Blues tested Mark Gillespie for the first time as McDaid went for goal from wide but the keeper was down to meet the effort.On  minutes, the home dugout were raging after referee Steven McLean awarded the visitors a soft free-kick on the edge of the area after letting a challenge on Graham Dorrans go.And Motherwell made it count as Long#s strike from  yards took a heavy deflection off Dorrans to find the bottom corner and give the Premiership side the lead.Six minutes later Dundee were almost level as Kane Hemmings jumped with the #Well goalie and headed goalwards but Richard Tait was there to clear off the line.Just seconds later it was - as Polworth played in Long and the striker made no mistake, curling past Hamilton to put his side firmly in control.At the break, new boy Callachan came on to make his debut and there was almost an immediate response in the second half as Hemmings turned a Dorrans free-kick onto the bar on  minutes.Seconds later McDaid flashed a -yard effort just wide as the Dark Blues tried to get back into the contest.There was a lot more le about the home side second half and substitute Danny Johnson almost made an instant impact off the bench, taking on his old side and shooting just wide with his first involvement.McDaid was proving a real threat and his deflected effort on  minutes almost squeezed through to Hemmings before Cammy Kerr met a Dorrans cross with a flicked header but only found the goalie#s arms.Two minutes later the contest was over.Long had his hat-trick and it was a gt from Dee keeper Hamilton. The striker hit one from distance that seemed simple for the goalie but he fumbled it into the corner to knock the stuffing out of his team.Long could have added a late fourth but fired wide after beating Jordan McGhee with three minutes to go.It made no dference, however, as #Well dumped Dundee out of the cup.Dundee: Hamilton, Kerr, McGhee, Meekings, Marshall, Ness , Byrne , Dorrans, McGowan , McDaid, Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie, Forster, Robertson, Strachan.Motherwell: Gillespie, Tait, Gallagher, Hartley, Carroll, Polworth , O#Hara, Campbell, Hylton , Long, Scott .Subs not used: Carson, Mugabi, Grimshaw, Manzinga.Attendance: ,

title: dundee united 2 2 hibs appere solo goal earns united cup replay
story: Louis Appere earned Dundee United a Scottish Cup fourth-round replay as they twice came from behind to draw with Hibs.Christian Doidge gave the Hibees a dream start after eight minutes at Tannadice before Lawrence Shankland scored a classy equaliser in first-half stoppage time.Martin Boyle put the visitors back in front with a powerful drive on  minutes before substitute Appere curled home a leveller on  minutes which earned the Terrors an Easter Road replay and a place in the hat for the last- draw.United showed five changes from the team which faced Partick last weekend with Jamie Robson, Calum Butcher, Ian Harkes, Peter Pawlett and Paul McMullan coming in for Adrian Sporle, Declan Glass, Nicky Clark, Louis Appere and Mark Reynolds.It was Pawlett#s first start for almost three months, with McMullan and Harkes seeing their first action since the last Dundee derby.What had been billed as the tie of the round got off to a frenetic start. And it was the visitors who almost took the lead after three minutes. However, Mark Connolly was in the right place at the right time to clear Florian Kamberi#s effort off the line.Hibs weren#t to be denied five minutes later, though, as they opened the scoring through a low Doidge effort. Slipped in by former Dundee man Boyle, the Welsh hitman coolly slotted under Benjamin Siegrist for -.On  minutes, straight from a United corner, the Hibees broke. Boyle was again the creator-in-chief, with his surging run into the Terrors# half leaving United back pedalling before Melker Hallberg saw his shot foiled by Siegrist.Kamberi again fired towards his fellow-countryman just before the half-hour but this time it was an easy save for United#s Swiss stopper.The Tangerines were struggling to get a foothold in the match and had created few chances as proceedings approached the half-way point. When Liam Smith found Harkes at the edge of the box to fire in a fairly innocuous shot, however, the mood seemed to lt around Tannadice.On  minutes, Siegrist again halted a deflected Kamberi effort from a matter of yards as the Hibees continued to press. United were starting to enjoy more possession, though, and went in at half-time with the tie level thanks to Shankland#s th domestic goal of the season.In the last of three minutes of added time at the end of the first period, Harkes strolled through the heart of the Hibs defence before sliding in Shankland to slot home from eight yards despite being under heavy pressure.United weren#t level for long, though, as two minutes into the second period the men from Edinburgh were back in the lead.Scott Allan played provider as he laid in Boyle to drive home low beyond an outstretched Siegrist from fully  yards.Kamberi#s battle with Siegrist continued on  minutes with the goalie again denying the striker#s thunderbolt from distance with the rebound just evading Boyle on the follow-up.Allan fired over just after the hour as the Terrors, again, fell out of the game as boss Robbie Neilson ordered their first change of the afternoon, sending Appere on for Pawlett.And young attacker Appere had the desired impact  minutes after coming on, picking up possession on the left before twisting and turning away from Steven Whittaker and then David Gray to curl a delightful effort beyond the helpless Ofir Marciano for -.Both teams pushed for a winner in the closing  minutes, with Siegrist pulling off a top save from Doidge in injury time, but it never came, meaning these two will have to do it all again a week on Tuesday in the capital.Dundee United : Siegrist , Smith, Watson, Connolly, Robson Harkes , Butcher , Powers McMullan, Shankland, Pawlett .Subs not used: Deniz, Sporle, Reynolds, Sow and King.Hibs : Marciano , Naismith , Porteous , Hanlon , Stevenson Hallberg, Allan, Whittaker Boyle, Doidge, Kamberi.Subs: Bogdan , Slivka, Newell, Horgan and Shaw.Ref: Kevin Clancy.Att: ,.

title: fan excitement part and parcel of our success
story: Dundee United fans are enjoying the ride as their team seemingly sail to the Championship title but star striker Lawrence Shankland is keen to make sure they have a safe passage to glory.United breezed past Partick Thistle on Saturday with a - win at Firhill to open up what looks like an unassailable -point gap at the top of the table.The , Arabs who made the trip to Glasgow certainly revelled in their day out as Shankland notched a perfect hat-trick to complement Adrian Sporle’s first league goal for the Terrors.However, Shanks insists the squad are avoiding the hype and keeping their feet on the ground but does understand supporters’ eagerness to celebrate their potentialto the Premiership after a four-year absence.“It’s part and parcel but we’ll leave getting excited to the fans and we’ll stay focused on our job,” the -goal hitman said.“We know what we need to do and get done until then.“There’s a lot of tough fixtures coming up for everybody and there’ll be hard games we’re involved in so the more points we pick up every week the better it’ll be for us.”Shankland was delighted to be back on the scoresheet in Maryhill after two games without finding the back of the net.And the -year-old hopes to keep up his fine form with a view to getting back into the Scotland squad.He sees involvement in Steve Clarke’s plans as a bonus but would love the chance to add to his two caps and help fire Scotland to a major tournament when the Euro  play-offs kick off in March.“It was something I saw as more of a bonus,” he added.#I was involved in the last two squads but I’m not going to go out there and call myself a Scotland regular, as much as I would like to be!“I’m not going to get too caught up in it and,I’m not selected, I’m not going to be too broken-hearted about it.“I’ll be looking to keep getting on the scoresheet, working hard and,I keep playing and scoring goals, then I’ll give myself the best chance.”Tangerines talisman Shankland has stolen a lot of the headlines this season for his goal-scoring form, speculation surrounding his future and his emergence on to the international scene .However, he knows he wouldn’t have been able to excel like he has without the help of United boss Robbie Neilson and his coaching staff.And Shankland ranks the Tannadice gaffer up there with the best.AskedRobbie was the best manager he’d worked with, Shankland said: “I couldn’t pick out one, to be honest.“Every manager is dferent and they’ve all got dferent qualities so it’s hard to say.“Robbie has been particularly good to work with, that’s reflected in the performances you’re seeing from the boys.“We’ve had a lot of good results in the last two months and he just gives you your job to go and do.“It’s always clear what your instructions are for a game.“The main thing for a player is knowing that because, evenit goes wrong, you know the game plan and how to eradicate any problems that arise.“It’s clear what we’re doing every week and I think that helps going out to do it on the pitch.“Sometimes when we’re in the form we’re in we can go out and play but sometimes we need a bit more information.“That does help because sometimes as a player you miss things managers see in terms of opposition qualities and places you can get at them.“Himself, Jigand Gordygive us a lot of information going into games and it does help.”

title: birdwatch volunteers sought
story: Members of the public are being encouraged to sign up to take part in a bird conservation charity event.It is hoped those living in the north-east will take part in the RSPB’s Big Garden Birdwatch, to showcase the wildle living in the area.The event takes place from January  to .The more people who take part, the better picture the charity has over the UK, and issues faced in dferent areas, such as the north-east of Scotland.It is the world’s largest annual wildle survey and involves spending an hour counting all the birds that visit your garden or local park over three days.Results can be submitted online until February , or by post until the th of next month.Blackbirds, blue tits and chaffinches are often spotted.More information can be found on the RSPB website.

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: refurbished statue is back in rightful place in north east town centre
story: A refurbished statue which looks out across a north-east town centre has been painstakingly ed home.The repaired effigy of Alexander Fraser, the th Lord Saltoun, sat above the door of the council chambers on Fraserburgh’s Saltoun Square since .But the harsh weather took its toll and left the statue without a face. vw, px"  As part of a near-£ million regeneration scheme in Fraserburgh the figurine was removed, and for the last few months, stone conservator Karolina Allan has been trying to give him a new look.With the work complete, the statue has been hoisted back into its original home, which will now be known as the Faithlie Centre.The former council chamber will be an enterprise centre to help start-up businesses as part of a £.m revamp.Specialist teams were in Fraserburgh yesterday to supervise the heavy stone statue being lted into place.Banff and Buchan area committee vice-chairman Mike Roy said it was “exciting” the effiguy had been ed to its “rightful place”.He added: “Karolina’s excellent work has transformed the statue and is a great symbol of the detailed work and traditional skills being used bring this historic building back into use.“We are all very much looking forward to the Faithlie Centre becoming a hub of local activity once again.” vw, px"  Brian Topping, chairman of the Fraserburgh Regeneration Development Partnership, said he was pleased to see progress on part of the major project for the town was moving forward.He said: “Bringing the Faithlie Centre back into use is a major part of the regeneration work currently taking place in Fraserburgh, and I am sure everybody will pleased to see Lord Saltoun overlooking the square once again.“The investment in the town will bring new and improved opportunities for Aberdeenshire Council, our partners and the public and this marks a great start for the year ahead.”Alexander Fraser was known as the “Waterloo Saltoun” after fighting in the Napoleonic Wars.The statue was created by London-based sculptor Edward Stephen and arrived in , six years after Lord Saltoun died.

title: smoothie bar plans approved
story: Plans to turn a former Aberdeen pub into a cafe have been approved.The change of use application for Cutter’s Wharf on Regent Quay were originally submitted in July last year by All Designon behalf of Kenny Swan.The proposals for the site, which was formerly the location of a pub, have now been approved by planning officers.According to floor plans, there will be several tables seating four, as well as booth and window seating.A smoothie bar will be on the right hand side of the building, with a kitchen and store room at the rear.There will also be several toilets, including a disabled facility.Daniel Lewis, development management manager at Aberdeen City Council said: “The proposed change of use and its associated extraction system would not adversely affect the character and visual amenity of the surrounding area.”

title: teams future to be reviewed
story: A team of  north-east officers have helped to make sure their colleagues get rest days, a new report said.Police Scotland created a Brexit contingency team – also called the force reserve – in March last year.It was made up of  officers across the country, including  who were drafted in from the north-east during at least two periods, each lasting several weeks.They were deployed to major events such as Old Firm football derbies and environmental street protests so they are trained for problems that may arise from leaving the European Union.In a new Scottish Police Authority report, Deputy Chief Constable Will Kerr highlighted the team’s availability to be drafted into police major events has led to fewer of their colleagues being called up on rest days.He said: “The positive impact on service delivery and staff wellbeing – through reduced cancelled rest days – the force reserve has been recognised.”The report said Police Scotland spent £.m preparing for Brexit as of January  – funded by the UK Government.Deputy Chief Constable Kerr added: “A review is being undertaken and will consider a range of options going forward. Upon completion of the review an options paper will be presented, for consideration of the Chief Constable Iain Thomas Livingstone, by the end of January.“Options will include full or part retention or full stand down of force reserve and officers ed to ision.“This decision will be taken against the operational backdrop of a number of signicant operational challenges during , including Euro  football matches and the United Nations Climate Change Conference .”
